Note.text: If you'd like specialized in-person help, San Mateo County offers in-person help for restraining orders Mondays from 8am to 12 noon and 1:30 to 3pm at the Self-Help office on the 6th floor

DV0.text: What do you need help with?

DV1.text: Ask for a new restraining order

DVCheck1.text: Do you want protection from someone who has abused you or your children? (Abuse can be physical, emotional, financial, or take place online)

DVCheck2.text: Are they someone you: dated, married, or had an intimate relationship with, or are related to (parent, child, sibling, grandparent — by birth or marriage?

DVStart.text: You may qualify for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order

DVTiming.text: Note: If you file for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order before noon, you should get a response from the court that same day.

DVMinor.text: If you're under 12, a trusted adult must help you file. Please contact the Self-Help Center in-person or online via LiveChat for assistance.

DVAlt.text: You may qualify for a different restraining order: Civil Harassment, Elder Abuse, Workplace Violence

DVNotQual.text: A restraining order is only available if there has been abuse. You may want to speak to a legal aid provider about other options.

DVForms.text: To start a Domestic Violence Restraining Order (DVRO), fill out required forms

DV100a.text: Step 1: Fill out DV-100 (Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order)

DV2.text: Respond to a restraining order someone else filed

DV3.text: Change or end an existing restraining order

DV5.text: Renew a restraining order before it expires

DVCQ.text: Have a question about filling out the DV100? View common questions here:

DVQ2.text: Is it free to file a DVRO?

DVQ3.text: Can I ask for a DVRO if I already have a criminal protective order?

DVQ4.text: How fast can I get protection?

DVQ5.text: Can I get a DVRO if I'm under 18?

DVQA.text: What if I don't remember the exact dates?

DVQA2.text: What if I need more space?

DV100f.text: If you don't remember the exact date, estimate and explain (e.g., 'Around August 2020')

DV100d.text: If you need more space, attach MC-025 (Attachment Form) or use blank paper

Proof1.text: If you have proof (texts, emails, photos), attach it to your request

DV100b.text: In DV-100, item 5: Describe the MOST recent abuse first — give specific facts

DV100c.text: Use item 6 and 7 to describe earlier abuse, including the worst incidents

CLETSa.text: Step 2: Fill out CLETS-001 (Confidential CLETS Information). Only the court and law enforcement see this. The other party does NOT get a copy.

DV109a.text: Step 3: Fill out DV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing). You only complete items 1 and 2 — the court fills out the rest

DV110a.text: Step 4: Fill out DV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order Request). You only complete items 1, 2, and 3 — the court fills out the rest.

DVReview.text: Once forms are filled out, go to the Courthouse clerk to file them and ask for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), or you may be able to e-file online at the court website

DVOptional.text: Do you also want to request other orders such as child custody or visitation, child support or spousal support?

DVPickup.text: Ask the clerk when your papers will be ready and how you'll be notified.

DVRead.text: When you get your forms back, read DV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing) and DV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order) carefully

DVCheckOrders.text: Was a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) granted? Check if the judge signed DV-110

DVTROYes.text: You now have a Temporary Restraining Order. It lasts until your court date. Keep a copy of DV-110 with you at all times. You can also take photos of it on your phone

DVTRONo.text: A TRO was not granted, but you still have a court date where you can provide more information to support granting a restraining order

DVServePrep.text: You must now serve the other person with your court papers. Someone 18 or older (not you or someone protected by the order) must personally deliver the documents before your court date - the sherrif or someone else may be able to do this for you

ServeWho.text: Would you like the Sherrif to servce your papers for you? You must have the address or location of the other person.

SERStart.text: Step 1: Fill out form SER-001 (Request for Sheriff to Serve Court Papers)

AltStart.text: Step 1: Choose your server. The server must be 18 or older and not involved in your case. You cannot serve the papers yourself

Attendhearing.text: Attend your hearing at the court on the day listed on item 3 on the DV109 you recieved. If you have evidence like pictures, text messages, or emails, you will need to print them out and make three copies of each piece of evidence. One copy is for you, one is for the judge, and one is for the other side. If you have witnesses who can help support your case, bring them with you to your court date.

DVA1.text: A DVRO can: Stop contact, harassment, or threats, require the person to stay away, make them move out, restrict firearm access, require support payments, create custody/visitation rules. It can also protect children, pets, and property. Police can enforce a CLETS restraining order.

DVA2.text: Yes. There is no court fee to ask for a DVRO. You also do not need a lawyer to file.

DVA3.text: Yes. A DVRO may still be helpful because: Criminal cases can be dismissed, and DVROs can include child custody, support, or family protection. You can have both at the same time.

DVA4.text: If you ask for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), the judge usually decides within 1 business day after you file.

DVA5.text: Yes, if you're 12 or older, you can file on your own. The court may ask for a trusted adult to help. If you're under 12, an adult must file for you.

DVA6.text:
Domestic violence is a pattern of behaviors used to gain or maintain power and control through:
        - physical or sexual violence
        - coercion and threats
        - intimidation
        - emotional abuse
        - isolation
        - minimizing, denying and blaming abuse on victim
        -  economic abuse

RespStart.text: If you recieved any of the following forms: DV-109, DV-100, or DV-110, this means someone asked the court for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order against you

DVRenewStart.text: Do you want to renew (extend) a restraining order before it expires?

DVREntry.text: Do you want to change or end a restraining order that is still active?

edges.when: No, I would like someone else to serve it for me
